title: Essex lorry deaths: Hunt for second driver caught on CCTV at port in Belgium
text:

Police are searching for a second lorry driver in connection with the deaths of 39 people found in a trailer after he was filmed 10 times at a Belgium port.

CCTV cameras at Zeebrugge captured the HGV as it went through the terminal on its way to Pursfleet and then Grays in Essex, where the mound of dead bodies were found on Wednesday morning.

Dutch language newspaper Het Nieuwsblad has quoted a source thought to be a Belgium official who suggested authorities on the continent are now searching for the lorry's driver before it crossed the Channel.

"We hope to catch him soon," they are quoting as saying.

"His truck was filmed 10 times at the port site."

So far four people have been arrested in connection with the tragedy.

(Image: PA)

Shortly after he called paramedics to the scene at 1.40am on Wednesday, officers arrested 25-year-old Mo Robinson on suspicion of murder.

The Northern Irish man remains in custody after local courts granted Essex Police permission to continue questioning him for a second time yesterday.

On Friday afternoon a 38-year-old man and woman of the same age from Warrington in Cheshire were held on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and 39 counts of manslaughter.

(Image: Peter Powell)

It is thought they are Joanna and Thomas Maher, a husband and wife who told MailOnline they previously owned the Scania lorry but sold it to a company in Ireland a year ago.

Yesterday evening a 48-year-old man from Northern Ireland was arrested at Stansted Airport on the same charges as the couple.

It is thought that the trailer containing the 39 dead people is owned by a firm in Dublin.

At 2.49pm on Tuesday it arrived in Zeebrugge before it was placed on a ferry bound for Purfleet where it arrived at 1am the next day.

It is believed most, if not all, of the victims were dead when Robinson picked up the container a short while later.

Police investigating on Friday night declined to speculate on reports of the suspected Vietnamese victims.

(Image: Peter Powell)

Some Vietnamese families have shared their fears their relatives were in the lorry container.

They included the distraught family of one woman thought to be among the dead who sent a harrowing final text message to her mother late on Tuesday night.

Pham Thi Tra My, 26, wrote: “I’m sorry Mum. My journey abroad hasn’t succeeded. Mum, I love you so much. I’m dying because I can’t breathe.”

For years, illegal immigrants have stowed away in lorries while attempting to reach Britain, often from the European mainland.

In 2000, 58 Chinese nationals were found dead in a tomato lorry at the port of Dover.

(Image: PA)

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said UK police were still carrying out their verification work and at present are not able to verify the nationalities of the deceased.

"We hope that the British side can as soon as possible confirm and verify the identities of the victims, ascertain what happened and severely punish criminals involved in the case," she told a daily news briefing.

Hua said that no matter where the victims were from, the case was an enormous tragedy.

The international community should strengthen their cooperation on fighting illegal immigration and on communication and intelligence to prevent such incidents from happening again, she said.

The Chinese embassy in London said it has sent a team to Essex to coordinate with the police.

(Image: BBC)

Reuters reports that the widely-read Chinese tabloid the Global Times said in a Friday editorial that at the moment it was impossible to say how much responsibility the dead should bear for the tragedy.

"But such a serious humanitarian disaster has occurred under the eyes of the British and Europeans," it said.

"It is clear that Britain and relevant European countries have not fulfilled their responsibility to protect these people from such a death."

Even if the victims were found to have been smuggled into the country, their deaths were not their fault, added the paper, which is published by the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily.

Britain appears not to have learned its lesson from the Dover incident two decades ago, it added.

"Imagine how thoroughly European countries would take measures if dozens of Europeans were collectively tragically killed in some way," the paper said.

"Could the British and European people ask themselves why they have not been able to avoid a similar tragedy...Did they take all the serious remedial action that they could have?"

On Friday Deputy Chief Constable of Essex Police Pippa Mills called on anyone with information about the people inside the lorry to come forward.

“I would like to speak directly to anyone who thinks their loved ones may have been in the trailer," she said.

(Image: REUTERS)

"I know you may be worried about speaking to the police. I would like to reassure you that we just want to be able to give the victims’ families answers about what has happened.

"I can’t begin to comprehend what some of you must be going through right now. You have my assurance that Essex Police will be working tirelessly to understand the whole picture to this absolute tragedy.

“I would also like to make an appeal to anyone living illegally in this country, who could help our investigation. Please come forward and speak to us without fear. I can assure you that your information will be received in strictest confidence and no criminal action will be taken against you."
description: Police in Belgium are reportedly hunting for a second lorry driver following numerous sightings of his truck at Zeebrugge port
